    Highlights

    •
    PTI alkalinizes the acidic extracellular pH in root meristem
    •
    Alkalinization impairs the acidic-dependent RGF1 signaling on root meristem growth
    •
    Alkalinization promotes the Pep1-PEPRs binding and enhances root immunity
    •
    Sulfotyrosine and Glu/Asp function as pH sensors on RGF1 and PEPRs, respectively

    Summary

    The extracellular pH is a vital regulator of various biological processes in plants. However, how plants perceive extracellular pH remains obscure. Here, we report that plant cell-surface peptide-receptor complexes can function as extracellular pH sensors. We found that pattern-triggered immunity (PTI) dramatically alkalinizes the acidic extracellular pH in root apical meristem (RAM) region, which is essential for root meristem growth factor 1 (RGF1)-mediated RAM growth. The extracellular alkalinization progressively inhibits the acidic-dependent interaction between RGF1 and its receptors (RGFRs) through the pH sensor sulfotyrosine. Conversely, extracellular alkalinization promotes the alkaline-dependent binding of plant elicitor peptides (Peps) to its receptors (PEPRs) through the pH sensor Glu/Asp, thereby promoting immunity. A domain swap between RGFR and PEPR switches the pH dependency of RAM growth. Thus, our results reveal a mechanism of extracellular pH sensing by plant peptide-receptor complexes and provide insights into the extracellular pH-mediated regulation of growth and immunity in the RAM.

    Graphical abstract

    Keywords

    1. extracellular pH
    2. pH-sensing
    3. alkalinization
    4. plant peptide
    5. receptor-like kinase
    6. RGF1
    7. Pep1
    8. sulfotyrosine
    9. pattern-triggered immunity
    10. root meristem

    ).
    In this study, we report that the extracellular pH can be sensed by peptide receptors in the RAM. Using molecular, biochemical, and genetic analyses, we found that the extracellular acidic pH environment in the RAM is altered by the immunity-triggered extracellular alkalinization. The extracellular pH change can be sensed by RGF1 and Pep1 receptor complexes. The alkalinization attenuates the relatively acidic pH-dependent RGF1-RGFR interaction to inhibit RGF1 signaling and the proliferation of RAM. The alkalinization enhances the relatively alkaline pH-dependent Pep1-PEPR interaction to promote immune response. The key pH-sensing residues in RGF1 and PEPR1 are identified as sulfotyrosine and Glu/Asp, respectively. Swapping the extracellular domains of RGI1/RGFR4 and PEPR1 can switch the pH dependency of RAM development. Thus, our findings uncover how plants sense extracellular pH signals in the RAM to fine-tune growth and immunity.

    Results

    Pattern-triggered immunity alkalinizes the extracellular pH in the RAM

    Extracellular alkalinization is the hallmark of the plant PTI response (Boller and Felix, 2009

    Boller, T. ∙ Felix, G.

The image analysis of wild-type (Col-0) Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings grown on standard MS media (pH 5.7) revealed a relatively acidic apoplast pH environment in the RAM, with the lowest pH around the region of the quiescent center (QC) (Figures 1A and S1A). When the seedlings were transiently treated with the DAMP molecule Pep1, the extracellular pH surrounding the RAM, especially near the QC, significantly increased (Figures 1B and 1C). Treatments using the PAMP molecules (flg22 and elf18) showed similar results to the Pep1 treatment, albeit to a lesser extent (Figures 1D and 1E). We then tested Pep1, flg22, and elf18 treatments in the Pep1 receptor mutant pepr1 pepr2 (pepr1/2). Pep1 was unable to induce RAM alkalinization in pepr1/2 (Figures 1F and 1G), suggesting that the extracellular alkalinization requires PEPR1/2-mediated signaling. The flg22 and elf18 treatments could not induce RAM alkalinization in pepr1/2 either (Figures 1F and 1G), suggesting that flg22- and elf18-induced alkalinization in the RAM depends on Pep signaling. This result is consistent with the finding that Pep signaling is required for the flg22- and elf18-induced immune response (Ma et al., 2012

    Extracellular alkalinization is sufficient to inhibit RGF1 signaling

    Given that the region of Pep1-induced extracellular alkalinization in the RAM (Figure 1B) overlaps with the expression region of RGF1/2/3 and the PLT1/2 (Figure S3A) (Galinha et al., 2007
    23.
    Galinha, C. ∙ Hofhuis, H. ∙ Luijten, M. ...
    PLETHORA proteins as dose-dependent master regulators of Arabidopsis root development
    Nature. 2007; 449:1053-1057
    Crossref
    Scopus (666)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Matsuzaki et al., 2010
    51.
    Matsuzaki, Y. ∙ Ogawa-Ohnishi, M. ∙ Mori, A. ...
    Secreted peptide signals required for maintenance of root stem cell niche in Arabidopsis
    Science. 2010; 329:1065-1067
    Crossref
    Scopus (363)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), we assessed whether extracellular alkalinization per se could induce the inhibition of RGF1 signaling and RAM growth. The proton pump activator fusicoccin (FC) and the pump inhibitor N, N′-dicyclohexylcarbodiimide (DCCD) were used to introduce cell autonomous pH changes. Consistent with their modes of action, the HPTS image analysis revealed that FC and DCCD triggered the apoplastic acidification and alkalinization in the RAM, respectively (Figures 3A and 3B). No difference in RAM size was observed between the FC-treated and mock-treated Col-0 seedlings (Figures S3B and S3C), suggesting that further acidification has little effect on RAM growth, consistent with the acidic nature of its apoplast. By contrast, the DCCD treatment greatly impaired RAM size and the responsiveness to RGF1 in Col-0 (Figures S3B and S3C) and in aqc1-1 (Figures 3C and 3D), a loss-of-function mutant lacking TPST that exhibits enhanced sensitivity to exogenous RGF1 treatment (Matsuzaki et al., 2010
    51.
    Matsuzaki, Y. ∙ Ogawa-Ohnishi, M. ∙ Mori, A. ...
    Secreted peptide signals required for maintenance of root stem cell niche in Arabidopsis
    Science. 2010; 329:1065-1067
    Crossref
    Scopus (363)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Zhou et al., 2010
    93.
    Zhou, W. ∙ Wei, L. ∙ Xu, J. ...
    Arabidopsis tyrosylprotein sulfotransferase acts in the auxin/PLETHORA pathway in regulating postembryonic maintenance of the root stem cell niche
    Plant Cell. 2010; 22:3692-3709
    Crossref
    Scopus (145)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Interestingly, DCCD did not have an effect on RAM growth in aqc1-1 without exogenous RGF1 treatment (Figures 3C and 3D). Together, these data indicate that extracellular alkalinization triggered by a proton pump inhibitor is sufficient to inhibit RGF1-induced RAM growth.
    We next investigated the pH response of RGF1 signaling using different medium pH conditions. Consistent with the FC and DCCD treatments, the medium pH conditions markedly induced apoplastic pH change (Figures S3D and S3E). Not considering the potential buffering capacity of the root apoplast, we conducted a HPTS calibration using Col-0 seedlings grown on different medium pH conditions and approximately estimated that the pH value near the QC region was less than 4.7 (Figures S3D and S3F). To maximize the effect of exogenous RGF1 peptide application in different pH conditions, the aqc1-1 mutant that possesses little basal RGF1 bioactivity was used (Zhou et al., 2010
    93.
    Zhou, W. ∙ Wei, L. ∙ Xu, J. ...
    Arabidopsis tyrosylprotein sulfotransferase acts in the auxin/PLETHORA pathway in regulating postembryonic maintenance of the root stem cell niche
    Plant Cell. 2010; 22:3692-3709
    Crossref
    Scopus (145)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The RGF1-induced RAM growth in aqc1-1 was significantly inhibited at pH 6.7 and 7.2 (Figures 3E and 3F). The imaging of PLT2-YFP fluorescence in aqc1-1 also showed that the RGF1-induced expression of PLT2 was notably attenuated at pH 6.7 and 7.2 relative to pH 4.7 and 5.7 (Figures 3G and 3H and S3G). The pH effect on Col-0 plants was consistent with that of aqc1-1 mutant (Figures S3H and S3I). These results suggest that RGF1 signaling is substantially impaired when the pH of the growth medium is increased from 5.7 to 6.7 or 7.2.
    We further monitored the pH effects on the RGF1 receptor quadruple mutant rgi1,2,3,4. The FC or DCCD treatment and different pH conditions were unable to induce inhibition of RAM size in rgi1,2,3,4 (Figures 3I–3L). Together with the finding that DCCD had no effect on RAM size in aqc1-1, these results suggest that alkalinization-induced RAM growth inhibition is mainly achieved through RGF1 signaling and that RAM growth becomes largely independent of pH without an intact RGF1 signaling pathway.

    The pH-sensing mechanism underlying RGF1 recognition by RGFR

    To elucidate the molecular mechanism underlying the pH dependency of the formation of the RGF1-receptor complex, we first measured the binding affinities of RGF1 to RGI3/RGFR1LRR at different pH conditions using isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC). Although they exhibited a strong interaction at pH 6.0, the interaction was completely disrupted at pH 8.0 (Figure 5A). We also found pH-dependent interactions between RGI3/RGFR1 and the other five RGF peptides (RGF 2, 3, 4, 5, and 8) (Figures S5A and S5B). Interestingly, RGF6, RGF7, and RGF9 peptides were recently found to be involved in leaf-specific immune response (Stegmann et al., 2022; Wang et al., 2021

    A pH change disturbs the protonation states of the polar residues, which might consequently affect the polar interaction between RGF1 and its receptor RGFRs (Figure S4B). Our previously solved crystal structure of the RGF1-RGI3/RGFR1 complex (Figure 5B) (Song et al., 2016

An examination of the complex structure revealed two histidine residues from RGF1 (H7 and H8) involved in the polar interaction that have a pKa value within this range (Figures S4B and S5D; Table S1); however, these two histidine residues are not conserved in other RGFs (Figure S5E), excluding their possible role in pH sensing. Tyrosine has been shown to function as a pH sensor in the arginine antiporter AdiC, which responds to pH change in the range of 5.5–6.5 through cation-π interaction (Wang et al., 2014

    Posttranslational sulfation is essential for the bioactivity of the RGFs and their interaction with their receptors (Matsuzaki et al., 2010

    Bruice, P.Y.
    Organic chemistry

    To provide further evidence in planta, we synthesized a desulfated RGF1 peptide (dRGF1). dRGF1 was previously shown to be capable of inducing RGFR-mediated signaling, albeit with a much lower activity than sulfated RGF1 (Fernandez et al., 2013
    21.
    Fernandez, A. ∙ Drozdzecki, A. ∙ Hoogewijs, K. ...

Taken together, these results support that the sulfotyrosine is the pH sensor for RGF1 signaling.

    Extracellular alkalinization promotes Pep1 signaling

    Previously, an in vitro pull-down assay showed that the interaction between Pep1 and PEPR1LRR was dependent on pH (Tang et al., 2015
    81.
    Tang, J. ∙ Han, Z. ∙ Sun, Y. ...
    Structural basis for recognition of an endogenous peptide by the plant receptor kinase PEPR1
    Cell Res. 2015; 25:110-120
    Crossref
    Scopus (131)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Here, we used a gel-filtration assay to monitor the Pep1-induced PEPR1LRR interaction with the co-receptor BAK1LRR under different pH conditions. The gel-filtration data showed that PEPR1LRR interacted with BAK1LRR in the presence of Pep1 at pH 6.0 or 8.0; however, the Pep1-induced PEPR1LRR-BAK1LRR interaction was completely disrupted at pH 4.0 (Figure 6A), in contrast with the case of RGF1-RGFR interaction.
    We next studied the alkaline pH-dependent manner of Pep1 signaling in vivo. We first examined the pH effect on Pep1-induced RAM growth inhibition. Both an acidic pH (pH 4.7) and treatment with the proton pump activator FC greatly attenuated Pep1-induced RAM growth inhibition, suggesting that this process is dependent on a relatively alkaline pH (Figures 6B and 6C). Given our abovementioned finding that an acidic pH also enhanced RGF1 signaling, this attenuation may be attributed to a combinatory effect of an acidic pH-induced inhibition of Pep1 signaling and promotion of the RGF1 signaling. We then measured the pH effect on the Pep1-induced Ca2+ influx, an early immune response marker using cytosolic Ca2+ imaging. A [Ca2+]cyt spike was observed after treatment with Pep1 at pH 5.7; however, the [Ca2+]cyt spike was less pronounced at pH 4.2 (Figure 6D), suggesting that the Pep1-induced Ca2+ influx is promoted by a relatively alkaline pH. Furthermore, we measured the expression of MYB51, a downstream immune response gene of Pep1 (Dhar et al., 2021
    15.

Consistently, a recent study reported that ROS production, another downstream event of Pep1 signaling, was suppressed in the root by an acidic extracellular pH (Yu et al., 2019

    The pH-sensing mechanism underlying Pep1 recognition by PEPR

    We previously reported the structure of the PEPR1LRR-Pep1 complex (Tang et al., 2015
    81.
    Tang, J. ∙ Han, Z. ∙ Sun, Y. ...
    Structural basis for recognition of an endogenous peptide by the plant receptor kinase PEPR1
    Cell Res. 2015; 25:110-120
    Crossref
    Scopus (131)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Based on the structure, we identified numerous Asp/Glu-mediated polar interactions at the Pep1-PEPR1 interface (Figures 6F and S6). The side chains of Asp and Glu, with pKa values of 3.86 and 4.25 (Table S1), may undergo protonation when the solution pH decreases to 4.0, in turn disrupting the hydrogen bond network mediated by Asp/Glu (Dobrev et al., 2017
    16.
    Dobrev, P. ∙ Donnini, S. ∙ Groenhof, G. ...
    Accurate three states model for amino acids with two chemically coupled titrating sites in explicit solvent atomistic constant pH simulations and pK(a) calculations
    J. Chem. Theory Comput. 2017; 13:147-160
    Crossref
    Scopus (23)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The Asp/Glu residues may therefore be the potential pH sensor for the relatively alkaline-dependent Pep1-PEPR1 interaction. The MM-PB/SA calculations showed that the free energy ΔG of the PEPR1LRR-Pep1 binding was −4.75 kcal/mol at pH 6.0 but changed to +51.49 kcal/mol when Asp and Glu were protonated at pH 4.0 (Figure 6G), suggesting that the acid-induced protonation of the Asp and Glu residues largely disrupts the PEPR1LRR-Pep1 interaction.
    To further verify the pH-sensing role of the Asp/Glu residues, we introduced substitutions of three of the most conserved Asp/Glu residues (D273N, E324Q, and D348N) into PEPR1 (Figures 6H and 6I). Glu and Asp are charged amino acids, and the α-carboxylic acid groups in their side chains are deprotonated at physiological pH (Dobrev et al., 2017
    16.
    Dobrev, P. ∙ Donnini, S. ∙ Groenhof, G. ...
    Accurate three states model for amino acids with two chemically coupled titrating sites in explicit solvent atomistic constant pH simulations and pK(a) calculations
    J. Chem. Theory Comput. 2017; 13:147-160
    Crossref
    Scopus (23)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The side chains of Gln/Asn are similar to that of Glu/Asp, respectively, except that the carboxylic acid group is replaced by an amide. For this reason, Gln/Asn are charge-neutral polar amino acids that could substitute for Glu/Asp to form similar but relatively weak polar contacts with no protonation or deprotonation change in acidic pH (Hauser and Barth, 2007
    31.
    Hauser, K. ∙ Barth, A.
    Side-chain protonation and mobility in the sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+-ATPase: implications for proton countertransport and Ca2+ release
    Biophys. J. 2007; 93:3259-3270
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (30)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The substitution of Asp/Glu with Gln/Asn therefore mimics the intermediate state during the pH-induced deprotonation-protonation transition. A pull-down assay showed that the PEPR1D273N and PEPR1E324Q mutants largely compromised the Pep1-PEPR1 interaction (Figures 6I and 6J), suggesting that the polar interactions of these two acidic residues are critical. Strikingly, compared with the wild type, the PEPR1D348N mutants exhibited a weak interaction with Pep1 even at pH 4.0 (Figure 6J), supporting the essential role for this Glu residue in pH sensing. Interestingly, Asp and Glu residues are also found critical for low pH-dependent lysosomal cholesterol egress by NPC1 and NPC2 (Qian et al., 2020
    69.
    Qian, H. ∙ Wu, X. ∙ Du, X. ...
    Structural basis of low-pH-dependent lysosomal cholesterol egress by NPC1 and NPC2
    Cell. 2020; 182:98-111.e18
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (108)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).

    A chimeric receptor leads to a pH-dependent switch of RAM growth

    To provide more definitive evidence to support the finding that extracellular pH is distinctively sensed by the RGF1 and Pep1 peptides binding to their cognate cell-surface receptors, we engineered a chimeric receptor, PEPR1LRR-RGI1/RGFR4TM+KD, in which the extracellular domain of RGI1/RGFR4 was replaced by that of PEPR1 (Figure 7A). This chimeric receptor was expressed in the pepr1/2 mutant driven by the native promoter of RGI1/RGFR4, so that the Pep1 signal should only be recognized by the chimeric receptor, which leads to the activation of RGF1 signaling instead of Pep1 signaling. Upon treatment with Pep1, the PEPR1LRR-RGI1/RGFR4TM+KD transgenic plants grown on MS medium (pH 5.7) indeed showed a significant increase in RAM size and meristematic cell number (Figures 7B and 7C), demonstrating that the chimeric receptor is functional. We then examined the pH response of the transgenic plant. If our findings regarding the pH-sensing mechanism hold true, we would expect a switched pH dependency during RAM growth. Intriguingly, the pH dependency of RAM growth in the transgenic plant was switched from an acidic pH-dependent manner to a relatively alkaline-dependent manner (Figures 7B and 7C). This result confirmed that (1) the interaction of Pep1-PEPR1 is relatively alkaline dependent; (2) the acidic-dependent RAM growth is mediated by RGF1 signaling; and (3) the pH dependency is determined by the extracellular domain rather than the intracellular domains or downstream signaling steps. Thus, this domain-swapping assay provides compelling evidence to support our findings of the extracellular pH-sensing mechanism and regulation in the RAM.

    Discussion

    The acidic nature of the plant apoplast and changes in the extracellular pH in response to biotic and abiotic stresses have been known for decades (Boller and Felix, 2009

    43.
    Lager, I. ∙ Andréasson, O. ∙ Dunbar, T.L. ...

    PubMed

    ). In this study, we uncover that the signals triggering PTI response could alter the acidic pH environment in the RAM, which is essential for the cell division of RAM. We further discover that extracellular pH change could be sensed by RGF1 and Pep1 peptide signaling. The alkalinization of the RAM apoplast inhibits the acid-dependent RGF1-RGI/RGFR interaction to inhibit RAM growth. On the other hand, this alkalinization facilitates the relatively alkaline-dependent Pep1-PEPR1 interaction to promote the immune response. Interestingly, swapping the extracellular domains of RGI1/RGFR4 and PEPR1 switches the RAM growth from a relatively acidic-pH-dependent manner to a relatively alkaline-pH-dependent manner. These findings elucidate a mechanism that extracellular pH sensing in plants is mediated by distinctive cell-surface peptide-receptor complexes. By modulating the binding affinity of the peptide ligands to their cognate receptors, the extracellular pH fine-tunes growth and immunity in the RAM (Figure 7D).

Consistently, Yu et al. (2019)

     reported that a commensal rhizosphere-associated Pseudomonas could acidify root extracellular pH by the secretion of organic acid to inhibit root immunity, suggesting that microbes may utilize plant pH regulation mechanism to counteract plant immunity. In addition, we also found that altering medium pH was sufficient to change RGF1 and Pep1 signaling. Given that the root apoplast is an important interface with soil, it is likely that pH sensing in the RAM may also be involved in response to abiotic stress, such as salinity or drought-induced extracellular alkalinization, although further investigation is needed.
    A noteworthy finding of this study is the identification of sulfotyrosine in RGF1 peptide as a pH sensor. Posttranslational sulfation is essential for the bioactivity of RGFs and their interaction with their receptors (Matsuzaki et al., 2010
    51.
    Matsuzaki, Y. ∙ Ogawa-Ohnishi, M. ∙ Mori, A. ...

    ). Here, we have provided multiple lines of evidence to support that the sulfotyrosine is also critical for sensing pH. We firstly narrowed down the pKa value of pH sensor to pH 6.0–7.0 by examining pH-dependent formation of RGF1-RGI1-SERK1 complex. Then, we evaluated the possibility of the residues involved in the polar interaction of RGF1 and RGIs and identified the sulfotyrosine as a possible pH sensor. We next conducted MD simulation to show that the free energy of sulfotyrosine-mediated interaction was much lower at acidic pH than at alkaline pH. Finally, we synthesized a de-sulfated RGF1 peptide and observed dRGF1-induced RAM growth in a pH-independent manner. Our genetic data showed that aqc1-1, a mutant lacking endogenous tyrosyl-protein sulfotransferase (TPST) activity, lost pH dependency of RAM growth. By contrast, the pH-dependent RAM growth was re-established in aqc1-1 upon treatment of synthesized RGF1 but not dRGF1 peptide, which confirmed the pH-sensing role of sulfotyrosine. Notably, HPTS, which was used as a pH indicator in this and many previous studies (Barbez et al., 2017

    Limitations of the study

    We focused on understanding how PTI-triggered extracellular alkalization is sensed by RGF1 and Peps peptide-receptor complexes in the root meristem zone. Additional studies into extracellular pH sensing by RGF-RGFR and Pep-PEPR in other tissues and even other receptor-like kinase-mediated pH-sensing processes will be a critical next step in further delineating the mechanisms of plant extracellular pH perception. In addition, we show that not only PTI-triggered alkalization but also altering medium pH was sufficient to change RGF1 and Peps signaling response. Thus, future studies of abiotic stress-triggered extracellular alkalization and plant-microbe interaction-induced extracellular pH changes could be performed to verify our findings. Another limitation of the study is the measurement of absolute pH values in the apoplast. Although HPTS has been used as a powerful pH indicator to track the relative change of extracellular pH, the absolute pH values in the apoplast cannot be directly read from HPTS fluorescence. Thus, further technological advances are needed for accurately measuring extracellular pH.

    Experimental model and subject details

    Bacteria strain

    E. coli DH5α was cultured at 37°C in LB medium for plasmid DNA extraction. E. coli BL21 (DE3) was cultured at 37°C in LB medium for protein expression. E. coli DH10Bac was cultured at 37°C in LB medium for bacmid production. A. tumefaciens GV3101 was cultured at 28°C in LB medium for plant transformation. Pseudomonas was cultured at 25°C in TSB medium for plant infection.

    Insect cell line

    Insect cell strain Spodoptera frugiperda (Sf21) and Trichoplusia ni (High Five) were cultured for protein purification. Cells were cultured in Sf-900 II SFM medium (Gibco) at 28°C with 120 rpm in shaking incubator. Baculovirus infected cells were cultured at 28°C with 120 rpm for 60 h.

    Method details

    Growth conditions for plants and chemical treatment

    Arabidopsis seeds were plated on Murashige and Skoog medium (4.4 g/L MS salts, 1 % [w/v] sucrose, pH 5.7, and 0.8% [w/v] agar) in petri dishes after surface-sterilization in 70% ethanol and 0.1% Triton X-100. The dishes were stored at 4 °C for 3 days, and then vertically placed in an incubator with a 16/8 h light/dark cycle at 22 °C in 70% humidity to grow.
    Different pH MS medium was adjusted by KOH.
    FC (Santa cruz) and DCCD (Sigma-Aldrich) were dissolved in DMSO as 5 mM stocks, frozen at -20 °C, and RGF1, dRGF1, Pep1, flg22 and elf18 peptides were dissolved in double distilled water as 100 mM stocks. These chemicals were dissolved to final concentration (5 μM FC and DCCD, 10 nM Pep1, 100 nM RGF1, flg22 and elf18, 5 μM dRGF1 unless specified labeled) in MS medium before solidification.

    Culture conditions for bacteria and inoculation

    Culture conditions for Pseudomonas R401 and R569 were performed as previously described (Ma et al., 2021
    46.
    Ma, K.W. ∙ Niu, Y. ∙ Jia, Y. ...
    Coordination of microbe-host homeostasis by crosstalk with plant innate immunity
    Nat. Plants. 2021; 7:814-825
    Crossref
    Scopus (88)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with minor modifications. Bacterial strains were inoculated on 50% tryptic soy broth (TSB) agar plates from the glycerol stock, and incubated at 25°C overnight. Before use, strains were cultured in 50% TSB liquid medium to saturation, and subcultured to log phase with fresh medium at a 1:100 ratio. Bacterial cultures were pelleted by centrifugation at 5 000× g for 5 min, followed by two washes with 10 mM MgSO4. After washing, bacteria were diluted with 10 mM MgSO4 to an OD600 of 0.005. Bacterial suspension was dripped on the roots of 4-day-old seedlings, and incubated for 6 h, followed by HPTS staining assay.

    Root length measurement

    For quantitative root length measurement, 3-day-old Col-0 and pepr1/2 seedlings were transferred to fresh MS medium with or without Pep1 to continuously grow for 4 days. Images of 7-day-old seedlings were captured using a digital camera. Roots were measured using ImageJ software (NIH). The experiments were repeated at least three times with similar results.

    Confocal microscopy

    For confocal microscopic analysis, 4-day-old (Col-0 background and RGI1/RGFR4pro:PEPR1LRR-RGI1/RGFR4TM+KD/pepr1 pepr2) or 5-day-old (aqc1-1 and rgi1,2,3,4 background) seedlings were transferred to the respective MS medium for 12 h (RGFR1pro:PEPR1LRR-RGFR1TM+KD/pepr1 pepr2), 1 day (Col-0 and rgi1,2,3,4) or 2 days (aqc1-1). The seedlings were stained with 10 μM propidium iodide for 5 min, gently washed with double distilled water, and mounted on glass slides and analyzed at 600-640 nm for propidium iodide or 525-565 nm for YFP using a confocal microscope (Zeiss LSM880).
    The numbers of root meristematic cells were obtained by counting the cortex cells from the cell proximal to the QC to rapid elongated cell. The cell length of root mature cells was obtained by measuring the length of epidermal cells in differentiation zone using ImageJ software (NIH). The fluorescence intensity was measured using ImageJ software (NIH). The experiments were repeated at least three times with similar results.

    HPTS staining

    HPTS staining was performed as previously described (Barbez et al., 2017
    5.
    Barbez, E. ∙ Dünser, K. ∙ Gaidora, A. ...
    Auxin steers root cell expansion via apoplastic pH regulation in Arabidopsis thaliana
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2017; 114:E4884-E4893
    Crossref
    Scopus (228)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with minor modifications. 4-day-old seedlings grown on standard MS medium were mounted in different pH or treatment MS medium supplemented with 1 mM HPTS on a microcopy slide for 2 h before observation. For bacteria-treated samples, seedlings were mounted on 1 mM HPTS-contained MS medium for 30 min before observation. Values shown in the boxplots are relative 458/405 value to mock or pH 5.7 of the same region around root meristem. The signal aggregates were excluded during data processing. The experiments were repeated at least three times with similar results.

    Transient expression in Nicotiana benthamiana

    Transient expression in N. benthamiana was performed as described previously(Song et al., 2016
    75.
    Song, W. ∙ Liu, L. ∙ Wang, J. ...
    Signature motif-guided identification of receptors for peptide hormones essential for root meristem growth
    Cell Res. 2016; 26:674-685
    Crossref
    Scopus (135)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with minor modifications. Agrobacterium strains (GV3101) harboring above-described constructs were cultured in liquid Luria-Bertani medium overnight. The dense cultures were inoculated into fresh medium by 1:100 dilution and incubated for 6-8 h. The bacteria were sedimented and resuspended in infiltration buffer (5 g/L glucose, 10 mM MgCl2, 10 mM MES-KOH, pH 5.7) to an OD600 of 0.4∼1.0. The resuspended agrobacteria were infiltrated into tobacco leaves using 1 mL syringes without needles. For co-expression, resuspended bacteria containing different constructs were mixed to an OD600 of 0.4∼1.0. All tobacco tissues were recovered for 48 h before harvested.

    Co-immunoprecipitation and immunoblot assays

    The co-immunoprecipitation and immunoblot assays were performed as previously described (Song et al., 2016
    75.
    Song, W. ∙ Liu, L. ∙ Wang, J. ...
    Signature motif-guided identification of receptors for peptide hormones essential for root meristem growth
    Cell Res. 2016; 26:674-685
    Crossref
    Scopus (135)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with minor modifications. The expression of proteins of interest was tested by immunoblot assays at first. The tobacco leaves were rapidly frozen in liquid nitrogen after harvest, and ground into fine powder. A fraction of powder was added with an equal volume of 2× SDS sample buffer (4% SDS, 100 mM Bis-Tris pH 6.8, 10% glycerol, 2% β-mercaptoethanol), and incubated on ice for 15 min, followed by heating for 10 min at 65 °C. After centrifugation at 13 000× g for 5 min, the protein extracts were fractionated by 10% SDS-PAGE, blotted onto a PVDF membrane. Immunoblot assay was then performed using anti-GFP antibody (Chromo Tek) and anti-HA antibody (Santa Cruz).
    For co-immunoprecipitation, 500 μl well-expressed sample was distributed in each tube and homogenized in 1.5 mL ice cold PBS buffer (25mM NaH2PO4+Na2HPO4, 150 mM NaCl, 1 mM DTT, 0.1% NP-40, 1× protease cocktail inhibitor (Roche), pH value was adjusted by mixing different volume of NaH2PO4 and Na2HPO4). RGF1 and dRGF1 peptides were supplemented for 15 min, as indicated. Lysates were centrifuged twice at 13 000× g at 4 °C for 10 min. For input sample, 80 μl supernatant was transferred to a new tube and 20 μl of 5× SDS sample buffer (10% SDS, 250 mM Bis-Tris pH 6.8, 50% glycerol, 5% β-mercaptoethanol, and 0.05% bromophenol blue) was added. In all, 1.2 mL supernatant was transferred to a new tube to incubate with 10 μl GFP-trap agarose beads (Chromo Tec, Cat# Gta-200) for 2 h at 4 °C with gentle agitation. Next, the beads were washed six times with the corresponding pH PBS buffer, and centrifuged at 2 000× g at 4 °C for 2 min each time. A total of 60 μl 5× SDS sample buffer was added after the last wash. Subsequently, all the samples were boiled at 75 °C for 10 min. Proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE and analyzed by immunoblot assays using anti-HA antibody and anti-GFP antibody. Signals were either captured on X-ray film and developed using a Kodak MXP-102 or directly recorded using a Tanon 5200 Multi chemiluminescent imaging system (Tanon, Shanghai, China).

    Protein expression and purification

    All of the LRR proteins were expressed in High Five cells at 28 °C. One liter of insect cells (2 × 106 cells per mL) was infected with 30 mL baculovirus and the media were harvested after 60 h of infection. All of the proteins were purified using Ni-NTA (Novagen). After elution and concentration, the proteins were further purified by size-exclusion chromatography (Hiload 200, GE Healthcare) in buffer containing 10 mM Bis-Tris, pH 6.0, and 100 mM NaCl.

    Gel filtration assays

    The samples (RGI3/RGFR1LRR-SERK1LRR-RGF1 mixture and PEPR1LRR-BAK1LRR-Pep1 mixture) were incubated on ice for 1 h; then assayed by gel filtration (Hiload 200, GE Healthcare) in three pH buffers (10 mM citric acid, pH 4.0, 100 mM NaCl; 10 mM Bis-Tris, pH 6.0,100 mM NaCl; and 10 mM Tris, pH 8.0, 100 mM NaCl). The peak fractions were used for SDS-PAGE followed by Coomassie blue staining.

    Isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC) assays

    ITC200 was used to quantify the binding affinity of RGF1 with RGI3/RGFR1LRR. The protein samples for ITC were prepared in buffers with different pH (10 mM Bis-Tris, pH 6.0, 100 mM NaCl; and 10 mM Tris, pH 8.0, 100 mM NaCl). The titrations were performed at 25 °C. The stirring speed was 750 rpm. 1mM RGF peptide was injected into the stirred calorimeter cells containing 0.05 mM RGI3/RGFR1LRR. All of the ITC data were analyzed using MicroCal Origin 7.0.

    Computational Methods

    MD simulations for RGF1 and RGI3/RGFR1: The coordinates of residues Leu-96–Ser-514 of RGI3/RGFR1 in complex with RGF1 were taken from the crystal structure (PDB: 5HYX) (Song et al., 2016
    75.
    Song, W. ∙ Liu, L. ∙ Wang, J. ...
    Signature motif-guided identification of receptors for peptide hormones essential for root meristem growth
    Cell Res. 2016; 26:674-685
    Crossref
    Scopus (135)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) to use as an initial structure for MD simulations. The Amber ff14SB force field and the generalized Amber force field (GAFF) parameters were used for canonical amino acids and the sulfotyrosine (sTyr) residue, respectively. To examine the effect of pH in the MD simulations, we prepared three conditions: all histidine and sTyr residues of the RGI3/RGFR1 and RGF1 were protonated to simulate an aqueous solution at pH 6.0, all histidine residues were protonated but sTyr was deprotonated (referred to as dp-sTyr pH 6.0), and ε-protonated histidine and deprotonated sTyr were used for pH 8.0. The protein and ligand structures were solvated with the TIP3P water (Jorgensen et al., 1983
    39.
    Jorgensen, W.L. ∙ Chandrasekhar, J. ∙ Madura, J.D. ...
    Comparison of simple potential functions for simulating liquid water
    J. Chem. Phys. 1983; 79:926-935
    Crossref
    Scopus (33497)
    Google Scholar
    ) in a cubic box with edge lengths of 125 Å under periodic boundary conditions. Na+ or Cl− ions were included to neutralize the protein charge, then further ions were added corresponding to a salt solution of concentration 0.15 M. Protocols of energy minimization and equilibration of the system were previously described (Moriwaki et al., 2013
    56.
    Moriwaki, Y. ∙ Terada, T. ∙ Caaveiro, J.M. ...
    Heme binding mechanism of structurally similar iron-regulated surface determinant near transporter domains of Staphylococcus aureus exhibiting different affinities for heme
    Biochemistry. 2013; 52:8866-8877
    Crossref
    Scopus (21)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). After the equilibration, a production run was performed for each protonated state in the NPT ensemble at 300 K for 200 ns. Coordinates were saved every 10 ps. These MD simulations were performed using GROMACS 2018.5 package (Abraham et al., 2015
    1.
    Abraham, M.J. ∙ Murtola, T. ∙ Schulz, R. ...
    GROMACS: high performance molecular simulations through multi-level parallelism from laptops to supercomputers
    SoftwareX. 2015; 1–2:19-25
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (14546)
    Google Scholar
    ).
    MD simulations for PEP1 and PEPR1: Similar to the MD simulations for RGF1 and RGI3/RGFR1, an initial structure was taken from the coordinates of residues Leu-29–Gln-545 of PEPR1 in complex with PEP1 (PDB: 5GR8) (Tang et al., 2015
    81.
    Tang, J. ∙ Han, Z. ∙ Sun, Y. ...
    Structural basis for recognition of an endogenous peptide by the plant receptor kinase PEPR1
    Cell Res. 2015; 25:110-120
    Crossref
    Scopus (131)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). All histidine residues in the complex were protonated to simulate an aqueous solution at pH 6.0. For pH 4.0 acidic condition, all aspartate and glutamate residues were also set to be protonated along with the histidine. Force field, water models, and simulation procedure used for the complex were the same as for RGF1 and RGI3/RGFR1.
    Calculation of binding free energy using the MM-PB/SA method: The molecular mechanics–Poisson–Boltzmann/surface area (MM-PB/SA) method was employed to calculate the binding free energies for the complexes between RGFR1 and RGF1 in protonated and deprotonated conditions. The solvation free energy is the sum of polar (ΔGPB) and nonpolar (ΔGNP) parts. ΔGPB was calculated by solving Poisson–Boltzmann equation with interior and exterior dielectric constants of 2 and 80, respectively, with a salt concentration of 0.2 M. ΔGNP was determined on the basis of solvent accessible surface area (SASA): ΔGNP = 0.0378×ΔSASA − 0.5692 + ΔGdispersion, where SASA was the solvent accessible surface area and ΔGdispersion was the dispersion term(Tan et al., 2007
    79.
    Tan, C. ∙ Tan, Y.H. ∙ Luo, R.
    Implicit nonpolar solvent models
    J. Phys. Chem. B. 2007; 111:12263-12274
    Crossref
    Scopus (199)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The solvent probe radius used in the calculation of SASA was set at 1.4 Å. These calculations were performed using MMPBSA.py module in AmberTools 18.

    [Ca2+]cyt imaging of seedling roots

    To monitor peptide-induced change of [Ca2+]cyt, 7-day-old Col-0 seedlings expressing genetically encoded FRET-based Ca2+ sensor YC3.6 was used (Monshausen et al., 2008
    55.
    Monshausen, G.B. ∙ Messerli, M.A. ∙ Gilroy, S.
    Imaging of the Yellow Cameleon 3.6 indicator reveals that elevations in cytosolic Ca2+ follow oscillating increases in growth in root hairs of Arabidopsis
    Plant Physiol. 2008; 147:1690-1698
    Crossref
    Scopus (204)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Nagai et al., 2004
    61.
    Nagai, T. ∙ Yamada, S. ∙ Tominaga, T. ...
    Expanded dynamic range of fluorescent indicators for Ca(2+) by circularly permuted yellow fluorescent proteins
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2004; 101:10554-10559
    Crossref
    Scopus (898)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Seedlings were grown in PDMS RootChips as described (Grossmann et al., 2012
    36.
    Grossmann, G. ∙ Meier, M. ∙ Cartwright, H.N. ...
    Time-lapse fluorescence imaging of Arabidopsis root growth with rapid manipulation of the root environment using the RootChip
    J. Vis. Exp. 2012; 65:4290
    Google Scholar
    ), with each single root grown in an independent channel filled with liquid growth buffer (1/2 MS, 1% sugar, 10 mM MES, pH 5.7). YC3.6 imaging was taken by a Zeiss LSM 880 microscope, with excitation using the 458 nm line of the argon laser and emission collected at 484-505 nm and 526-536 nm for Ca2+-dependent CFP and cpVenus (FRET) fluorescence, respectively. All samples were pre-perfusioned with fresh medium of indicated pH for at least 15 min to equilibrate the extracellular pH condition. No perturbation of [Ca2+]cyt was found by simply pausing and restarting the perfusion that was needed for medium shifting.

    GUS staining

    5-day-old seedlings were collected and treated with 100 nM Pep1 in liquid MS medium at different pH for 6 h. After treatment, the seedlings were washed with staining buffer without X-Gluc, stained with GUS staining buffer (50 mM sodium phosphate buffer, pH 7.0, 10 mM Na2EDTA, 0.5 mM K4[Fe(CN)6]·3H2O, 0.5 mM K3[Fe(CN)6], 0.1% Triton X-100, and 1 mg/ml X-Gluc), incubated at 37 °C for 12 h, and then ethanol (70%) was used to terminate the staining reaction. The seedlings were cleared in chloral hydrate solution (chloral hydrate:water:glycerol = 8:2:1; w/v/v) for 5 min before observation. Pictures were taken using a Zeiss AxioImage A2 microscope. The experiments were repeated at least three times with similar results.

    Construction of plasmids

    To construct C-terminal GFP-tagged RGI1/RGFR4▵KD (pCHF3-RGI1▵KD-GFP), the kinase domain truncated RGI1/RGFR4 (1-2241 bp) was amplified using the primers pCHF3-Kpn I-RGI1 -Gib-F and pCHF3-RGI1dK-Bam HI-Gib-R from Arabidopsis Col-0 cDNA, and inserted into Kpn I and Bam HI sites of vector pCHF3-GFP by Gibson cloning. The Y258A and Y282A mutations on pCHF3-RGI1▵KD-GFP were generated with the help of primers RGI1-Y258A-mutant-F and RGI1-Y258-mutant-R, RGI1-Y282A-mutant-F and RGI1-Y282-mutant-R, respectively, using KOD-Plus-Mutagenesis Kit (TOYOBO).
    The kinase domain truncated SERK1 (1-825 bp) was amplified using the primers Sac I-SERK1-F and SERK1dK-HA-Kpn I-R from Arabidopsis Col-0 cDNA, and inserted into Sac I and Kpn I sites of vector pCAMBIA1307 (a derivative of pCAMBIA1300 by inserting CaMV 35S promoter sequence prior to multiple cloning site) to generate construct of pCAMBIA1307-SERK1▵KD-HA by restriction enzyme digestion.
    To express receptor LRR domains of RGI3/RGFR1 (residues 1–702), PEPR1 (residues 1–767), SERK1 (residues 1–213), and BAK1 (residues 1–220) protein in insect cell system, we generated C-terminal 6× His-tagged LRR proteins construction into the vector pFastBac1 (Invitrogen).
    To construct the chimeric receptor RGI1/RGFR4pro:PEPR1LRR-RGI1/RGFR4TM+KD-HA, native promoter of RGI1/RGFR4 (∼2 kb) was amplified using the primers pQG110-Pst I-RGI1pro-F and RGI1pro-PEPR1-R from Arabidopsis Col-0 genomic DNA, LRR domain of PEPR1 and transmembrane domain and kinase domain of RGI1/RGFR4 with epitope HA tag were amplified from Arabidopsis Col-0 cDNA using the primers RGI1pro-PEPR1-F and PEPR1LRR-RGI1TM-R, PEPR1LRR-RGI1TM-F and PEPR1LRR-RGI1TM-F, respectively. Then these three fragments were combined using the primers pQG110-Pst I-RGI1pro-F and pQG110-RGI1-HA-Sal I-R, and inserted into Pst I and Sal I sites of vector pQG110 by Gibson cloning. Of note, the sequence 5’ggcgtagtcaggcacgtcgtaaggata3’ in primer SERK1dK-HA-Kpn I-R and pQG110-RGI1-HA-Sal I-R encodes the HA tag.
    The oligonucleotide primers for all constructs are summarized in Table S2. All constructs described above were verified by DNA sequencing analysis.

    Quantification and statistical analysis

    All experiments involving measurements/quantifications, imaging and quantifications from images were repeated at least three times with similar results. Data plotting and statistical tests were performed in R. In graphs showing quantification, all data points (biologically independent samples, n) are plotted using box-and-whisker plot. In all graphs, asterisks indicate statistical significance (NS, not significant, ∗P<0.05; ∗∗P<0.01; ∗∗∗P<0.001) tested by Student’s t test (two groups), and lowercase letters indicate statistical significance tested between multiple groups by one/two-way ANOVA at p < 0.001.

    Manage Consent Preferences

    Strictly Necessary Cookies

    Always active

    These cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

    Functional Cookies

    These cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.

    Performance Cookies

    These cookies allow us to count visits and traffic sources so we can measure and improve the performance of our site. They help us to know which pages are the most and least popular and see how visitors move around the site.

    Targeting Cookies

    These cookies may be set through our site by our advertising partners. They may be used by those companies to build a profile of your interests and show you relevant adverts on other sites. If you do not allow these cookies, you will experience less targeted advertising.
